author: @BenderdickCumbersnatch
text: Just remember that Python is ALWAYS SINGLE-THREADED and that its "threads" are fake. They have something called the GIL (Global Interpreter Lock) which means that only 1 thread executes at a time.  Two threads cannot execute instructions at the SAME time.  They give the illusion of multithreading by implementing "let other threads do work while this function waits for data". It required that the functions are written to be asynchronous, such as time.sleep() or various file I/O functions.  But if you try non-asynchronous calls (things that internally block while waiting for the result) such as "a = b * c" or "a = numpy.zeros([10,10])", meaning most math operations and C libraries, then the whole "thread illusion" in Python falls apart. Each thread will then pause the whole program until each such operation is complete. Which means the "threaded" version will take longer to execute than single threaded.  The alternative which gives true multi-CPU execution is the "multiprocessing" module which spawns a separate Python process, but it is very slow to start and it transfers data in a slow way (serialized with pickle) between the main process and subprocess.  Python are working on a "subinterpreter" module which starts the extra process inside the main process which will be a bit faster but stil requires pickling the data.  In short the situation is bad. And Python will not remove the GIL to fix their threads because it would break all C modules and code that assumed that Python is always single-threaded... sigh.

author: @N00byEdge
text: The reason python threads slow down when doing CPU bound tasks is not because of the overhead of creating and taering down threads. It is actually just fine if you call a computation heavy native library.  The actual reason it slows down is because youâ€™re usually stuck in Python land where all threads share one lock, the GIL (global interpreter lock). This is released when youâ€™re doing sleep, I/O as seen in this video but also applies to other things. So you can only have one thread doing Python at a time, but many others doing system calls or running native code at the same time. If you ever write a python native library, you know the importance of releasing the GIL before entering your native code.

author: @pixelPlex
text: In addition to threads there are Coroutines which are similar to threads but are light weight, not dependent on a OS (scheduling is managed at the application/library level), and work in environments where multi-threading isn't supported (eg web browser with the JS platform). Python doesn't support the use of Coroutines directly like many other languages do (eg Kotlin - https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/coroutines-overview.html ; https://youtu.be/_hfBv0a09Jc ; https://youtu.be/a3agLJQ6vt8 ; https://youtu.be/hQrFfwT1IMo ), but Coroutines can be accessed indirectly via a library that uses a high level concurrency model (eg async/await via AsyncIO - https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html ).
